https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=989 87/251
C. Sale of Contraceptives: It shall be unlawful for any person to:
1. Vend, sell, distribute or give away in any manner whatsoever any article, drug or medicinal preparation, manufactured, produced
or intended for use, or which may be used as a contraceptive; provided, however, that the provisions hereof shall not apply to
regularly licensed practitioners of medicine, or drug stores employing a registered pharmacist, or any licensed retail business
within the City.
2. Vend, sell, give away or distribute any such articles, drugs or medicines for use as, or possible for use as, contraceptives, by
means of machines or peddling or canvassing within the City. The proprietor of any premises wherein any such drugs, medicines,
or articles are kept, contrary to the provisions of this subsection shall be presumed to be the vendor or distributor of the medicines,
drugs or articles. (1997 Code)
5-2-4: OFFENSES INVOLVING PUBLIC AND PRIVATE PROPERTY:
5-2-4-1: DAMAGE OR INJURY TO PROPERTY:
A. Injury To Public Property: It shall be unlawful for anyone to injure, deface or interfere with any property belonging to the City without
proper authority from the Council.
B. Damage To City Property: It shall be unlawful for any person to wilfully, deliberately or maliciously damage, deface, or in any way
render inoperative, any property owned or under the control and operation of the City. The word "property" as used hereinabove
means both real and personal property, including any locks, fences, gates, chains, padlocks or other devices or fixtures whatsoever
that may be installed upon or used in connection with property owned or operated by the City.
C. Malicious Injury To Property: It shall be unlawful for any person to wilfully and maliciously injure, deface, mutilate, remove, pull down,
break or in any manner interfere with or molest or secrete or destroy any real or personal property belonging to or under the control
of any person or of the City. [720 ILCS 5/21-1] (1997 Code)
5-2-4-2: OBSTRUCTION OF ANY SIDEWALK:
It shall be unlawful for any person to place or to leave any objects of any nature upon a sidewalk in the city or otherwise obstruct a
sidewalk. [65 ILCS 5/11-80-13] (1997 Code)
5-2-4-3: SNOW REMOVAL ON SIDEWALKS:
It shall be the duty of the owner or resident of premises adjoining any sidewalk in the city to remove any snow or ice from each sidewalk
within twenty four (24) hours after accumulation of such snow or ice. [65 ILCS 5/11-80-13] (1997 Code)
5-2-4-4: DEPOSITS OF REFUSE ON PUBLIC WAYS:
A. Deposits On Streets: It shall be unlawful for any person to:
1. Throw or deposit any glass, tacks, nails or other similar articles on any street, alley or sidewalk or other public place in the city.
2. Deposit, place or allow to remain in or upon any public thoroughfare any material or substance injurious to person or property.
3. Dump or deposit or cause to be dumped or deposited any grass, leaves, branches, or any other things in the roadway or gutter of
any public street in the city.
B. Windblown Refuse: It shall be unlawful to deposit or leave any refuse or material in such a place or condition that it can be blown by
the wind so as to be scattered or cause clouds of dust or particles; and it shall be unlawful to permit the escape of soot, ashes or
other solid products or results of combustion so as to be windblown or scattered. [65 ILCS 5/11-80-10, 605 ILCS 5/9-121, 625 ILCS
5/11-1413] (1997 Code)
5-2-4-5: FIRES; BURNING RESTRICTIONS:
A. Burning Leaves, Refuse, Garbage: It shall be unlawful for any person to:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=989 88/251
1. Burn leaves, tree branches, paper excelsior or other materials on Sunday, Monday, Wednesday and Friday. (Ord. 0-20-04, 12-27-
2004)
2. Burn any garbage, or other organic refuse, outside of any building at any time in the city.
3. Burn paper, excelsior or other material which may be blown about by the wind anywhere in the city unless the same is burned in a
stove, fireplace or furnace or in an incinerator with a screen sufficiently fine to prevent the escape of ignited particles.
4. Burn leaves, tree branches, paper, excelsior or other materials except between the hours of sunrise and sunset on the days
burning is permitted.
5. Start a fire that will not be constantly attended until it is completely extinguished. Fire control and extinguishing equipment must be
available to the person attending the fire.
6. Burn green grass and/or evergreen clippings.
B. Storage Of Combustible Refuse: It shall be unlawful to store or permit the storage of combustible refuse in such a way as to create a
fire hazard or to store or throw away any refuse of any kind in an alley, street, or public way in the city. [65 ILCS 5/11-8-4, 5/11-8-5]
C. Lighting Bonfires: It shall be unlawful to build or light any bonfire close to any building or structure, or on any asphalt street or
sidewalk pavement. [65 ILCS 5/11-80-2, 5/11-80-13] (1997 Code)
5-2-4-6: KEEPING JUNK RESTRICTED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to:
A. Store or keep any old articles or materials which may be classified as junk adjacent to or in close proximity to any schoolhouse,
church, public parks, public grounds, business buildings or residences without first providing proper and tight buildings for the
storage of the same. (1997 Code)
B. Keep a yard cluttered with abandoned junk or unused furniture, any white goods or appliances, car parts or junk piles, thereby
creating an unsightly nuisance in the neighborhood. (Ord. 98-09, 10-26-1998)
5-2-4-7: TRESPASSING:
It shall be unlawful for any person to take down any fence or to let down any bars or to open any gate in or on the property of another
without the consent of the owner, occupant or person in charge thereof. [720 ILCS 5/21-3] (1997 Code)
5-2-4-8: LETTING PREMISES FOR UNLAWFUL PURPOSE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to rent, use or allow to be used any building or property owned by such person for any purpose
whereby riotous or disorderly persons are gathered. (1997 Code)
5-2-4-9: BARBED WIRE, ELECTRIC FENCES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to erect or maintain any electric fence or any fence constructed in whole or in part of barbed wire or to
use barbed wire as a guard to any parking lot, stairway, entrance to a building or parcel of land. [65 ILCS 5/11-30-1] (1997 Code)
5-2-4-10: EXPECTORATING:
It shall be unlawful for any person to expectorate or spit upon any sidewalk or upon the floor of any public building or room used for
public assemblies. [65 ILCS 5/11-80-10] (1997 Code)
5-2-4-11: ABANDONED REFRIGERATORS:
It shall be unlawful to abandon any refrigerator, freezer or icebox or other device having an automatic lock on a compartment large
enough to enclose a human being in any place accessible to children without first removing the doors of such refrigerator, freezer or
icebox. [720 ILCS 505/1] (1997 Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=989 89/251
5-2-4-12: PLACEMENT OF OBJECTS ABOVE STREETS:
A. Scaffolds: Any scaffold or ladder placed in such a way that they overhang or could fall onto any public street, alley or other public
place in the City shall be firmly constructed and safeguarded; and it shall be unlawful to place or leave any tools or articles on any
such place in such a manner that the same could fall onto any such street, sidewalk, alley or other public place from a height greater
than four feet (4'). [740 ILCS 150/1]
B. Articles On Window Sills: It shall be unlawful for any person to place or keep on any window sill, porch or other projection above the
first story of any building abutting on any sidewalk any article which might do injury by falling upon any person on the sidewalk in
front of such building, unless said article be securely fastened or protected by screens. (1997 Code)
5-2-4-13: PROHIBITED ACTIVITIES IN STREETS:
A. Throwing Missiles: It shall be unlawful to cast, throw, or propel any missile on any street, alley or other public place.
B. Playing Ball, Other Games: It shall be unlawful for any person:
1. To play ball or throw any ball to and fro upon any public thoroughfare in the City.
2. To play any games upon any street, alley or sidewalk or other public place where such games cause unnecessary noise or
interfere with traffic or pedestrians. [65 ILCS 5/11-80-9]
C. Water Flowing Upon Streets: It shall be unlawful for any person to allow any water to flow into or upon any public thoroughfare. [65
ILCS 5/11-80-2] (1997 Code)
5-2-5: MISCELLANEOUS OFFENSES:
5-2-5-1: ADVERTISING, BILL POSTING RESTRICTIONS:
A. Unlawful Advertising; Injure Lawful Advertisements: It shall be unlawful to advertise any unlawful business or article in the City, and it
shall be unlawful to injure or deface any lawful advertisement or notice. [720 ILCS 295/1]
B. Advertising Matter In Motor Vehicles: It shall be unlawful for any person, whether a licensed bill poster or not, to distribute handbills,
circulars, dodgers, pamphlets, cards, pictures or any advertising matter of any kind whatsoever, by placing the same in or upon any
motor vehicle standing or parked in the public streets of the City.
C. Posting Bills: It shall be unlawful for any person to post any bills or advertisements on any public property without the authority of the
City; and it shall be unlawful to post any bill or advertisement on any property without the written consent of the owner thereof. [65
ILCS 5/11-80-14] (1997 Code)
5-2-5-2: BUSINESSES; PROHIBITED ACTS:
A. Junked Vehicles; Junk Shops Prohibited:
1. Junked Vehicle: It shall be unlawful for any individual, partnership, corporation or other business entity to carry on any business of
junking vehicles in the city. [65 ILCS 5/11-42-3]
2. Junk Shops: It shall be unlawful to operate or carry on the business of junking, junk dealing, or to keep any junk shop, store or
place for the purchase or sale of junk, rags, old rope, paper or bagging, old iron, brass, copper, or empty bottles. [65 ILCS 5/11-42-
3]
B. Unwholesome Business: It shall be unlawful to establish or conduct any packing plant, slaughterhouse, rendery, tallow chandlery,
soap factory, glue factory, tannery, or any offensive or unwholesome business within the city or within one mile of the limits thereof.
[65 ILCS 5/11-42-7, 5/11-42-9, 5/11-42-10; 740 ILCS 55/221 subdivisions 8 and 17]
C. Picketing: It shall be unlawful for any person, not an employee, past, present or expectant, of the owner or proprietor of the business
attempted to be picketed and who has no personal dispute with the owner or proprietor concerning terms and conditions of
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=989 90/251
employment to stand, sit or walk on any street or sidewalk in the city with the intent and purpose of dissuading or discouraging any
person from patronizing the place of business. (1997 Code)
5-2-5-3: PARKING OF CAMPERS; OWNERSHIP:
It shall be unlawful to park campers, trailers, etc., unless the person in possession of said camper or trailer can show proper title,
ownership or registration of such camper or trailer. (1997 Code)
5-2-5-4: HITCHHIKING:
It shall be unlawful for any person to stand or loiter upon any sidewalk, street, avenue, alley or public highway or grounds within the
limits of the city for the purpose of "thumbing", requesting, asking, or soliciting a ride from the operator of any motor vehicle. [625 ILCS
5/11-1006] (1997 Code)
5-2-5-5: WEAPONS OFFENSES:
A. Discharge: It shall be unlawful to discharge any firearm or air gun, BB gun, bow and arrow, or any toy gun projecting lead or any
missiles excepting in a regularly established shooting gallery; provided, that this subsection shall not be construed to prohibit any
officer of the law from discharging a firearm in the performance of his/her duty. [720 ILCS 535/3]
B. Concealed: It shall be unlawful to carry any concealed weapon in the city in violation of the laws of this state.
C. Furnishing To Prisoners: It shall be unlawful for any person to furnish or attempt to furnish or take into jail or to deliver or attempt to
deliver to any prisoner therein confined or in the custody of any officer, any weapon, tool, intoxicating liquors, drug or other article
without the consent of the officer in charge. [720 ILCS 5/31-6] (1997 Code)
5-2-5-6: LOUDSPEAKERS OR SOUND TRUCKS:
It shall be unlawful to play, operate, or use any device known as a sound truck, loudspeaker or sound amplifier, radio or phonograph,
tape deck or CD player, with loudspeaker or sound amplifier or any instrument of any kind or character which emits loud and raucous
noises and is attached to and upon any vehicle unless such person is in charge of such vehicle shall have first applied to and received
permission from the chief of police to operate any such vehicle so equipped. [65 ILCS 5/11-5-2] (1997 Code)
5-2-5-7: INJURY TO BIRDS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to kill or wound, or attempt to kill or wound, by use of a firearm, slingshot, bow and arrow or
otherwise, any bird other than English sparrows, or to take the eggs or young of any bird. (1997 Code)
5-2-5-8: JAYWALKING:
"Jaywalking" is defined as proceeding diagonally across a street intersection, or crossing a street between intersections, or at a place
other than a crosswalk. It shall be unlawful to jaywalk across Route 84 in the city of Colona, Illinois within the boundaries designated as
school zones by existing signs for such purposes. Enforcement of this section shall be strictly applied from thirty (30) minutes before the
school day commences and for thirty (30) minutes after school begins, and for thirty (30) minutes prior to the end of the school day and
for thirty (30) minutes after school shall have been dismissed. (Ord. 0-22-10, 12-27-2010)
5-2-6: DRUG PARAPHERNALIA2:
5-2-6-1: DEFINITION:
A. Definition: As used in this section, the following term shall have the meaning ascribed to it in this subsection:
DRUG PARAPHERNALIA: All equipment, products and materials of any kind which are used or intended for use in planting,
propagating, cultivating, growing, harvesting, manufacturing, compounding, converting, producing, processing, preparing, testing,
analyzing, packaging, repackaging, storing, containing, concealing, injecting, ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing into the
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=989 91/251
human body a controlled substance in violation of 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 550/1 et seq., and 570/100 et seq. It includes but is
not limited to:
1. Kits used, intended for use in manufacturing, compounding, converting, producing, processing, or preparing controlled
substances;
2. Isomerization devices used or intended for use in increasing the potency of any species of plant which is a controlled substance;
3. Testing equipment used or intended for use in identifying or in analyzing the strength, effectiveness or purity of controlled
substances;
4. Diluents and adulterants, such as quinine hydrochloride, mannitol, mannite, dextrose and lactose, used or intended for use, in
cutting controlled substances;
5. Separation gins and sifters used or intended for use in removing twigs and seeds from, or in otherwise cleaning or refining
marijuana;
6. Hypodermic syringes, needles and other objects used or intended for use in parenterally injecting controlled substances into the
human body;
7. Objects used or intended for use in ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing marijuana, cocaine, hashish, or hashish oil into
the human body, such as:
a. Metal, wooden, acrylic, glass, stone, plastic, or ceramic pipes with or without screens, permanent screens, hashish heads, or
punctured metal bowls;
b. Carburetion tubes and devices;
c. Water pipes;
d. Smoking and carburetion masks;
e. Roach clips; meaning paper clips, alligator clips, hairpins, or other similar objects that have been altered so that there exists a
handle attached to said object at an angle between forty five degrees (45) and one hundred thirty five degrees (135) so that
the alteration would facilitate a person's hold of burning materials such as a marijuana cigarette that has become too small or
too short to be held by the fingers and so that the alteration prohibits the use of said object for its normal function;
f. Cocaine spoons, and cocaine vials;
g. Chamber pipes;
h. Carburetor pipes;
i. Electric pipes;
j. Air-driven pipes;
k. Chillums;
l. Bongs;
m. Ice pipes or chillers.
B. Additional Considerations: In determining whether an object is drug paraphernalia, a court or other authority should consider, in
addition to all other logically relevant factors, the following:
1. Statements by an owner or by anyone in control of the object concerning its use;
2. Prior convictions, it any, of an owner, or of anyone in control of the object, under any State or Federal law relating to any controlled
substance;
3. The proximity of the object, in time and space, to a direct violation, by the object's owner or person in control of the object, of 720
Illinois Compiled Statutes 550/1 et seq., and 570/100 et seq.;
4. The proximity of the object to controlled substances owned by the object's owner or person in control of the object;
5. The existence of any residue of controlled substances on the object;
6. Direct or circumstantial evidence of the intent of the owner, or of anyone in control of the object, to deliver it to persons whom
he/she knows intend to use the object to facilitate a violation of 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 550/1 et seq., and 570/100 et seq.;
the innocence of an owner, or of anyone in control of the object, as to a direct violation of 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 550/1 et
seq., and 570/100 et seq., shall not prevent a finding that the object is intended for use, or designed for use as drug paraphernalia;
7. Instructions, oral or written, provided with the object concerning its use;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=989 92/251
8. Descriptive materials accompanying the object which explain or depict its use;
9. National and local advertising concerning its use;
10. The manner in which the object is displayed for sale;
11. Direct or circumstantial evidence of the ratio of sales of the objects to the total sales of the business enterprise; and
12. Expert testimony concerning its use. (1997 Code)
5-2-6-2: POSSESSION:
It is unlawful for any person to use, or to possess with intent to use, drug paraphernalia to plant, propagate, cultivate, grow, harvest,
manufacture, compound, convert, produce, process, prepare, test, analyze, pack, repack, store, contain, conceal, inject, ingest, inhale,
or otherwise introduce into the human body a controlled substance in violation of 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 550/1 et seq., and
570/100 et seq. (1997 Code)
5-2-6-3: MANUFACTURE OR DELIVERY:
It is unlawful for any person to deliver or possess with intent to deliver drug paraphernalia, knowing that it will be used to plant,
propagate, cultivate, grow, harvest, manufacture, compound, convert, produce, process, prepare, test, analyze, pack, repack, store,
contain, conceal, inject, ingest, inhale, or otherwise introduce into the human body a controlled substance in violation of 720 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 550/1 et seq., and 570/100 et seq. (1997 Code)
5-2-6-4: ADVERTISEMENT:
It is unlawful for any person to place in any newspaper, magazine, handbill, or other publication offered for sale within the City, any
advertisement, knowing that the purpose of the advertisement is to promote the sale within the City of objects designed or intended for
use as drug paraphernalia. (1997 Code)
5-2-6-5: PENALTY:
A. Individual: Any person who keeps for sale, offers for sale, sells, or delivers for any commercial consideration any item which that
person knows, or under all of the circumstances reasonably should have known, to be drug paraphernalia, commits a business
offense shall be subject to penalty as provided in Section 1-4-1 of this Code.
B. Business: Any store, place, or premises from which or in which any item of drug paraphernalia is kept for sale, offered for sale, sold,
or delivered for any commercial consideration is declared to be a public nuisance and the City Attorney may commence an action in
the Circuit Court, in the name of the People of the City of Colona, to abate a public nuisance as described in this subsection B, and
request that the Court enter: 1) temporary and permanent restraining orders to enjoin any defendant from maintaining such
nuisance, and 2) preliminary and permanent injunctions restraining any defendant from removing or interfering with any property
used in connection with the public nuisance.
C. Forfeiture: All drug paraphernalia is subject to forfeiture.
D. Seizure: Property subject to forfeiture under this Section may be seized by any peace officer and may be made without process:
1. If there is probable cause to believe that the property is directly dangerous to health or safety and existing circumstances do not
allow reasonable time for the office to obtain lawful process; or
2. In accordance with the provisions of the Code of Criminal Procedure, as amended.
The presence of items which are deemed violative of this Chapter or are otherwise subject to its forfeiture provisions in an
inventory shall not subject the entire inventory to seizure or forfeiture. (1997 Code)
5-2-7: DRUGS:
A. Cannabis: It shall be unlawful to use, or be under the influence of, cannabis or possess 2.5 grams or more of cannabis.
1. It shall be unlawful to possess less than 2.5 grams of cannabis.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=989 93/251
2. Anyone violating this Section shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) or more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). (Ord.
98-05, 7-13-1998)
Chapter 3
MINORS
5-3-1: CURFEW1:
A. Age And Hour Restrictions: It is hereby declared unlawful for a person less than seventeen (17) years of age to be present at or upon
any public assembly, building, place, street or highway at the following times unless accompanied and supervised by a parent, legal
guardian or other responsible companion at least eighteen (18) years of age and approved by a parent or legal guardian or unless
engaged in a business or occupation which the laws of Illinois authorize a person less than seventeen (17) years of age to perform:
1. Between one minute after twelve o'clock (12:01) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. Friday and Saturday.
2. Between eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. on Sunday to Thursday, inclusive, and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. on the following day.
Any person violating any provision of this subsection shall, upon conviction, be subject to penalty as provided in section 1-4-1 of
this code.
B. Parent, Guardian Responsible: It is hereby declared unlawful for a parent, legal guardian or other person to knowingly permit a
person in his or her custody or control to violate any provision of subsection A of this section. Any parent, legal guardian or other
person violating the provision of subsection A of this section shall, upon conviction, be subject to penalty as provided in section 1-4-1
of this code. (1997 Code)
5-3-2: CIGARETTE OR TOBACCO SALES2:
A. Sale Or Delivery: It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or give away, directly or indirectly, to any person under the age of eighteen
(18) years any cigarettes, tobacco, or any compounds of tobacco used in filling up or making up of a cigarette or to give or sell any
cigarette papers to minors.
B. Possession By Minors: It shall be unlawful by anyone under the age of eighteen (18) years to use or possess tobacco or tobacco
products within the city limits. (1997 Code)
5-3-3: DELIVERY OF ALCOHOL TO MINORS:
A. It shall be illegal and a violation of Colona ordinance for any person or business to deliver alcohol to a minor.
B. If a business within the city of Colona is accused or prosecuted by the state liquor commission or through a citation from the Colona
police department for the offense of delivery of alcohol to a minor, such business shall be required to appear before the Colona liquor
commission for an administrative hearing on such charges.
C. Any hearing before the city of Colona liquor commission to be had in accordance with subsection B of this section is to proceed prior
to any administrative hearing which is to be done by the city of Colona liquor commission.
D. If the Colona administrative hearing finds that alcohol has been delivered to a minor, the business or person who is found guilty shall
be subject to a fine being imposed against such person or business.
E. Penalty for a finding of violation of this section shall carry a fine to be imposed of a minimum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) with
a maximum of two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) which shall be the limits for a first time offense. Any hearing involving a
second offense for violation of this section shall carry a fine which will be at the reasonable discretion of the state liquor commission.
(Ord. 0-21-12, 12-10-2012)
Chapter 4
ANIMAL PROTECTION AND CONTROL1
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=989 94/251
ARTICLE A. ADMINISTRATION
5-4A-1: ANIMAL CONTROL OFFICER:
A. Position Created: The Animal Control Officer shall be appointed by the Mayor with the consent of the City Council.
B. Badge Of Office: While on duty, the Animal Control Officer shall wear a star engraved "Animal Control Officer" as an emblem of
his/her authority.
C. Residency: The Animal Control Officer shall reside within the City limits or within ten (10) miles of any City boundary line during the
term of employment.
D. Bond: The Animal Control Officer shall be bonded2.
E. Compensation: The salary of the Animal Control Officer shall be determined from time to time by a majority vote of the Mayor and
City Council.
F. Powers And Duties:
1. Supervision Of Animal Pound And Other Facilities: The Animal Control Officer shall have the care, custody, control, and
supervision of the animal shelter of the City and of animals confined and impounded, and shall have the care, custody, and control
of all trucks and equipment used by the Animal Control Officer or his/her assistants for the impounding of animals.
2. Remittance Of Fees: The Animal Control Officer shall deliver all fees and funds collected by the Animal Control Officer or his/her
assistants to the City Clerk at the end of each and every workday; excepting Saturdays, Sundays, and holidays.
3. Impoundment Of Animals; Records: The Animal Control Officer shall impound, or cause to be impounded, and shall dispose of
according to the provisions of this Chapter, all animals running at large within the City and shall keep a record of every animal so
impounded, describing the kind of animal, the breed, color, and sex, together with the time and place the animal was captured or
received and the final disposition made of each animal, together with such other information as may come to his/her attention.
4. Reporting: The Animal Control officer shall furnish a report to the City Council each month concerning the activities and financial
status of the animal control program. (1997 Code)
5-4A-2: FUNDS:
A. Funds Collected: All redemption fees, fines and license fees collected in accordance with the provisions of this Chapter shall be used
exclusively for animal control purposes, such as operations, salaries and for construction and maintenance of facilities necessary for
provisions of this Chapter.
B. Appropriation Of Funds: The City Council shall annually appropriate funds for the purpose of sustaining animal control activities.
(1997 Code)
5-4A-3: USE OF LOCAL VETERINARIAN:
The services of a local or nearby veterinarian may be sought for the medical care and/or necessary humane destruction of animals
specified in this Chapter and impounded in accordance with the provisions of this Chapter. The veterinarian shall be licensed in and by
the State. (1997 Code)
ARTICLE B. ANIMALS1
5-4B-1: RUNNING AT LARGE PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful to permit any dangerous or vicious animal of any kind to run at large within the City. Exhibitions or parades of
animals which are ferae naturae in the eyes of the law may be conducted only upon securing a permit from the Chief of Police. Anyone
found guilty of violating this section shall be subject to penalty as provided in section 1-4-1 of this Code. (1997 Code; amd. Ord. 0-19-01,
2-25-2019)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=989 95/251
5-4B-2: KEEPING CERTAIN ANIMALS PROHIBITED:
A. Disturbing The Peace: It shall be unlawful to harbor or keep any animal which disturbs the peace by loud or unusual noises2 at any
time.
B. Prohibited Animals: No person shall keep any cattle, sheep, goats, horses, mules, swine including potbellied pigs, or domestic fowl of
the species of geese, ducks, turkeys, guinea hens, or chickens at any place or upon any premises in the City, nor shall any such
animals be permitted to run at large within the City.
C. Beekeeping: No person shall keep or maintain any bees, beehives, or apiaries within the City. (1997 Code)
D. Penalty: Anyone found guilty of violating this section shall be subject to penalty as provided in section 1-4-1 of this Code. (Ord. 0-19-
01, 2-25-2019)
5-4B-3: ANIMAL YARDS:
A. Definition: As used in this section, the following words and terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection:
POULTRY OR ANIMAL YARD: Includes every enclosure, shed or structure used to house two (2) or more rabbits, or other domestic
animals.
B. Location: It shall be unlawful to maintain in the City any animal within twenty five feet (25') of any building used for residence
purposes by anyone other than the one maintaining such animal yard or his/her immediate family, or within twenty five feet (25') of
any public way, other than an alley, or within one hundred feet (100') of any church or school building.
C. Sanitary Condition: Every person maintaining an animal yard shall keep the same clean and sanitary, and free from all refuse. Such
yards shall be thoroughly swept at least once every twenty four (24) hours, and it shall be unlawful to permit any decaying food or
other refuse of any kind to remain in such yard. Refuse from such yards shall, when swept up or collected, be kept in airtight
containers until disposed of in accordance with this Code, and it shall be unlawful to permit any such refuse to remain recovered.
D. Enclosure Of Yard: Every animal yard shall be adequately enclosed so as to be impenetrable against rats or other rodents. The
presence of any rats in the animal yard shall be prima facie evidence that such yard is maintained in violation of the provisions of this
section.
E. Limitation Of Number Of Domestic Animals Other Than Dogs And Cats: No person shall harbor or keep over six (6) animals. (1997
Code)
F. Penalty: Anyone found guilty of violating this section shall be subject to penalty as provided in section 1-4-1 of this Code. (Ord. 0-19-
01, 2-25-2019)
5-4B-4: DANGEROUS ANIMALS:
A. Prohibited: No person shall permit any dangerous animal to run at large nor shall any person lead such an animal with a chain or
rope or other appliance, whether the animal is muzzled or unmuzzled, in any street, avenue, lane or highway or public place or
building within the City, except for public exhibition authorized by the Chief of Police.
B. Nuisance Declared: In addition to any other remedies, and except as expressly authorized in the City by the City Council, dangerous
animals are declared to be nuisances.
C. Disposition: If any dangerous, fierce or vicious animal cannot safely be taken up and impounded, the animal may be slain by any
police officer or animal control officer of the City. Any member of the Police Department, or any other person in the City, is hereby
authorized to kill any dangerous animal of any kind which threatens the safety of any person or property. However, in all cases where
any animal so slain has bitten any person or caused an abrasion of the skin of a person, it shall be the duty of the police officer
slaying the animal to immediately deliver the carcass and the head of the animal to the State Laboratory. Police officers shall not
shoot a rabies suspect in the head. (1997 Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=989 96/251
D. Penalty: Anyone found guilty of violating this section shall be subject to penalty as provided in section 1-4-1 of this Code. (Ord. 0-19-
01, 2-25-2019)
5-4B-5: BITING ANIMALS:
A. Report Of Animal Bites: All bites or attacks on human beings by any animal within the City shall be immediately reported to the Chief
of Police. In the event of a bite by an animal, a detailed report shall be made out by the receiving officer, including the complainant's
name, address and phone number; the name and address of the owner of the animal; a description and location of the wound, and
the name of the doctor treating the wound.
B. Administrative Search Warrant: In the event that the owner of any animal which has bitten a human refuses to turn the animal over to
the animal control officer, the animal control officer may obtain an administrative search warrant to enter the premises of the owner
and take possession of the animal. (1997 Code)
C. Penalty: Any person owning or keeping an animal that, without provocation or justification, bites or attacks a human being within the
City shall be subject to penalty as provided in section 1-4-1 of this Code. (Ord. 0-19-01, 2-25-2019)
5-4B-6: DISEASED ANIMALS:
A. Exposure: No domestic animal infected with a contagious or infectious disease shall be allowed to run at large or to be exposed in
any public place whereby the health of man or beast may be affected.
B. Shipping Or Removal From Premises: Such diseased animal shall not be shipped or removed from the premises of the owner
thereof, except under the supervision of the Chief of Police or proper health official. (1997 Code)
C. Penalty: Anyone found guilty of violating this section shall be subject to penalty as provided in section 1-4-1 of this Code. (Ord. 0-19-
01, 2-25-2019)
5-4B-7: CRUELTY TO ANIMALS:
No person shall be cruel to any animal. Cruelty to an animal shall consist of one of the following acts:
A. By overloading, overdriving, overworking, cruelly beating, torturing, tormenting, mutilating, or cruelly killing any animal or causing or
knowingly allowing the same to be done.
B. By unnecessary failing to provide any animal in his/her charge or custody as owner or otherwise, with proper food, drink, shelter and
air.
C. By abandoning any animal in a pound, veterinary clinic, or on the premises of another. (1997 Code)
Anyone found guilty of violating this section shall be subject to penalty as provided in section 1-4-1 of this Code. (Ord. 0-19-01, 2-25-
2019)
5-4B-8: ANIMAL FIGHTS:
No person shall instigate, cause or procure any dog fight, cock fight, or any public or private fighting of animals within the City. Anyone
found guilty of violating this section shall be subject to penalty as provided in section 1-4-1 of this Code. (1997 Code; amd. Ord. 0-19-01,
2-25-2019)
5-4B-9: INDECENT EXHIBITION:
No person shall in any manner instigate, cause, or procure or assist in any indecent or immoral show or exhibition of any animal within
the limits of the City. Anyone found guilty of violating this section shall be subject to penalty as provided in section 1-4-1 of this Code.
(1997 Code; amd. Ord. 0-19-01, 2-25-2019)
5-4B-10: TRAPPING:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=989 97/251
No person shall use any type of leg-hold animal trap or other animal trap that could cause cruelty to animals within the City limits without
the written approval, guidance and direction of the Health and Sanitation Department. Anyone found guilty of violating this section shall
be subject to penalty as provided in section 1-4-1 of this Code. (1997 Code; amd. Ord. 0-19-01, 2-25-2019)
5-4B-11: ANIMALS OWNED BY NONRESIDENTS; EXCEPTION:
A. Prohibited: No person who is not a resident of the City is permitted to keep any animal in the City. This prohibition shall not apply to
persons remaining in the City for thirty (30) days or less or who are passing through the City but shall apply to any nonresident who
habitually allows his/her animal to run at large within the City.
B. Disposition: Any animal found within the City which is not owned by a resident of the City or by a person passing through or
temporarily in the City shall be impounded by the animal control officer and disposed of as provided in this chapter for dogs or cats
not wearing a current inoculation tag.
C. Exception: The provisions of this section shall not apply to veterinary clinics, institutions and licensed dealers. (1997 Code)
D. Penalty: Anyone found guilty of violating this section shall be subject to penalty as provided in section 1-4-1 of this Code. (Ord. 0-19-
01, 2-25-2019)
5-4B-12: UNCLAIMED ANIMALS:
A. Unlicensed, Uninoculated Animals:
1. Whenever any reputable institution of learning, hospital, research laboratory, or their allied institutes which have been duly
licensed by the State in which the institution, hospital, laboratory or institute is located, and which is within a reasonable distance
of the City makes application to the animal control officer with consent of proper authority for permission to use humanely,
unclaimed and impounded animals for the good of mankind and the increase of knowledge relating to the cause, prevention, and
control and cure of disease, the animal control officer with consent of proper authority on being satisfied that the animals will be so
used, shall from time to time release such acceptable unclaimed, impounded animals for the purposes specified.
2. In order to give the owner/keeper of impounded animals time within which to reclaim them, no animal shall be surrendered
pursuant to subsection A1 of this section until such animal has been impounded for a period of at least seven (7) days.
B. Licensed, Inoculated Animals: No impounded animal wearing an unexpired rabies inoculation tag or a County license tag shall be
released for the purposes of medical research. (1997 Code)
C. Penalty: Anyone found guilty of violating this section shall be subject to penalty as provided in section 1-4-1 of this Code. (Ord. 0-19-
01, 2-25-2019)
5-4B-13: ANIMAL WASTES:
A. Control Required: No person owning, harboring, keeping or controlling any dog or other domestic animal or pet shall cause, suffer or
allow such animal to soil, defile, defecate on or commit any nuisance on any common thoroughfare, sidewalk, passageway, bypath,
play area, park, or any place where people congregate or walk or upon any public property whatsoever, or upon any private property
without permission of the owner of said property. The restriction in this section shall not apply to public property when the owner or
person in control of such animal complies with the following conditions:
1. The person who so curbs such animal shall immediately remove all feces deposited by such animal by any sanitary method.
2. The feces removed from the aforementioned designated areas shall be disposed of by the person owning, harboring, keeping, or
controlling any animal curbed in accordance with the provisions of this section in a sanitary manner approved by the local health
authority.
B. Penalty: Anyone found guilty of violating this section shall be subject to penalty as provided in section 1-4-1 of this Code. (1997
Code)
5-4B-14: BURIAL OF DEAD ANIMALS:
No owner or keeper of any animal which may die within the City shall leave the animal unburied for more than twelve (12) hours after its
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=989 98/251
death, or shall anyone bring and leave the carcass of any dead animal within the City. Anyone found guilty of violating this section shall
be subject to penalty as provided in section 1-4-1 of this Code. (1997 Code; amd. Ord. 0-19-01, 2-25-2019)
5-4B-15: ANIMALS IN FESTIVAL AREAS:
A. It shall be unlawful for anyone to have present a dog, cat, or other animal at any festival area except pursuant to a permit in the City.
B. This section shall not apply to:
1. Seeing eye dogs.
2. Horses or dogs used by law enforcement agencies in performance of their law enforcement duties.
3. Animals in a parade within the City.
4. Carnival vendors who bring in animals as part of their carnival and register the animals and obtain a permit from the City Clerk.
Said animals allowed by permit in this section may only be allowed in areas designated by the Colona Police Chief or his
designee.
C. "Festival area" is defined as that area providing or set up to provide entertainment, food, beverages, contests, carnival midways, or
any area within fifty feet (50') of the foregoing areas.
D. The "no contest" fine shall be seventy five dollars ($75.00) pursuant to the no contest ordinance.
E. The fine for violating this section shall be up to five hundred dollars ($500.00). (Ord. 99-08, 8-9-1999)
ARTICLE C. DOGS AND CATS1
5-4C-1: RUNNING AT LARGE PROHIBITED:
A. Definition: "Owner" or "keeper" as used herein shall mean any person having a right of property in a dog or cat or who keeps or
harbors a dog or cat or who has a dog or cat in his or her care or acts as a custodian of a dog or cat or who knowingly permits a dog
or cat to remain on or about any premises occupied by him or her.
B. Animals At Large:
1. Prohibited: No dog or cat shall be permitted or allowed to run at large within the city and shall be confined at all times on the
owner's or keeper's premises, or on a leash or on the owner's or keeper's premises under the control of a person physically able to
control such dog or cat.
2. Declared Nuisance: If found running at large, the dog or cat is hereby declared to be a public nuisance and shall be taken up and
impounded by the animal control officer or member of the police department in accordance with the provisions of this article.
3. Subject To Impoundment: Every dog or cat running at large within the city is subject to impoundment by the animal control officer.
4. Prima Facie Evidence: When any dog or cat shall be found running at large in violation of the provisions herein, it shall be prima
facie evidence that the owner or keeper of said dog or cat allowed and permitted the animal to run at large.
C. Penalty: Any person owning or keeping and permitting any dog or cat to run at large and not keeping such animal confined at all
times, except as otherwise provided herein, on the owner's or keeper's premises shall be subject to penalty as provided in section 1-
4-1 of this code. (1997 Code)
5-4C-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
A. Purchase Required: No dog or cat shall be permitted to be or remain in the city without being licensed as herein provided.
B. Annual Registration; Tag: Every owner of or person who keeps or harbors a dog or cat within the limits of the city shall report to the
clerk annually, within thirty (30) days after May 1 each year, his/her name and address, and shall give the name, breed, month of
birth, color and sex of each and every dog or cat owned, kept and harbored by such person and shall pay such license fee as
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=989 99/251
required in section 5-4C-4 of this article for male or female dogs or cats owned, kept or harbored, and shall cause such dogs or cats
to be registered in the Office of the City Clerk or animal control officer, who shall furnish the person paying the license therefor with
the metal tag or check as hereinafter provided.
C. Rabies Certificate: Every owner or person who harbors or keeps a dog or cat within the limits of the City shall, before securing
registration tags, exhibit to the Clerk or animal control officer a current County rabies certificate.
D. Penalty: Any person owning a dog or cat shall purchase a license as herein provided or be subject to penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this Code. (1997 Code)
5-4C-3: LICENSE TAGS, COLLAR REQUIRED:
A. Registry: The City Clerk or animal control officer shall keep a complete registry in a book kept for that purpose, of all licensed dogs or
cats describing the same by name, breed, color and sex, and shall also enter the name and address of the owner or keeper as
given, and the number of the City license, tag or check.
B. Tags Provided By City: The City Clerk or animal control officer shall also provide each and every year, such number of metal tags or
checks as may be necessary, having stamped thereon the year for which the license is issued, the letters "C.A.T.", and also the
number of the tag or check, and it shall be the duty of the City Clerk or animal control officer to deliver one of such tags or check
numbered to correspond with the registry of the animal, to the person having paid the license tax upon any such animal. The owner
of each animal being of the age of four (4) months or over must have a tag for such animal.
C. Collar Required: Every dog or cat over the age of four (4) months shall be provided by its owner or keeper with a collar to which shall
be securely attached and kept the license registration tag furnished by the City Clerk or animal control officer as hereinabove
provided.
D. Removal Of Collars, Tags Or Leashes: No person, other than the animal control officer, a police officer, or an owner shall remove the
collar, inoculation tag or leash from any dog or cat within the City without the consent of the owner or keeper of the dog or cat. Any
such removal shall subject the dog or cat to impoundment. (1997 Code)
E. Penalty: Anyone found guilty of violating this section shall be subject to penalty as provided in section 1-4-1 of this Code. (Ord. 0-19-
01, 2-25-2019)
5-4C-4: FEES:
A. License Fee: An annual license fee for dogs and cats shall be established by the City Council as may be necessary.
B. Violation Fees:
1. Failure To License Or Display License: The animal control officer shall issue to the owner or keeper of any unlicensed dog or cat
or the owner of any dog or cat failing to display the license tag a notice of ordinance violation.
2. Notice Of Ordinance Violation: A person receiving a notice of ordinance violation may, at his/her discretion, pay to the animal
control officer within seven (7) working days a sum established by the administrative fee schedule in subsection C of this section.
3. Failure To Comply: In the event no payment is received within the time period prescribed by the animal control officer, a formal
Municipal ordinance violation complaint shall be initiated in the Circuit Court.
C. Administrative Fee Schedule: The animal control officer is authorized to accept in full satisfaction of any notice of ordinance violation
the payment of the following administrative fees:
1. Twenty dollars ($20.00) for the first offense and forty dollars ($40.00) for each offense thereafter.
2. Proof of payment of fees imposed by section 5-4C-7 of this article.
3. The penalty for violating this section shall be a fine of twenty five dollars ($25.00) for the first offense and a fine of fifty dollars
($50.00) for each offense thereafter. (1997 Code)
5-4C-5: LIMITATION ON NUMBER:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=989 100/251
A. Number Allowed At Residence: No person in charge of a residence shall keep, harbor or control more than four (4) dogs, four (4)
cats, or a combination of four (4) at his/her residence. (1997 Code; amd. Ord. 08-05, 6-13-2005)
B. Unoccupied Residence: It shall be illegal and improper for any resident or nonresident of the City of Colona to house or keep animals
or pets of any nature at a residence which is unoccupied. (Ord. 08-05, 6-13-2005)
C. Penalty: Anyone found guilty of violating this section shall be subject to penalty as provided in section 1-4-1 of this Code. (Ord. 0-19-
01, 2-25-2019)
5-4C-6: INOCULATION:
A. Inoculation Required: Each owner or keeper of any dog or cat within the City shall cause the dog or cat to be inoculated by a licensed
veterinarian and shall maintain a current rabies inoculation for such dog or cat at all times. Current status shall be determined by the
rules and standards of the State Department of Agriculture and by the United States Department of Agriculture.
B. Inoculation Tag: The animal control officer shall be the official responsible for and charged with the duty of issuing the inoculation tag
evidencing the administration of a valid rabies inoculation required by subsection A of this section.
C. Attachment To Collar: Each dog or cat kept within the City shall be provided by its owner or keeper with a good and substantial collar,
and shall cause to be attached in a secure manner a current inoculation tag. The owner or keeper shall at all times cause the dog or
cat to wear the collar with inoculation tag attached.
D. Removal Of Tag: Any dog or cat found within the City, but off of the premises occupied by the owner of the dog or cat and not
wearing a collar with inoculation tag attached as required under this section shall be impounded and disposed of as provided in this
chapter. (1997 Code)
E. Penalty: Anyone found guilty of violating this section shall be subject to penalty as provided in section 1-4-1 of this Code. (Ord. 0-19-
01, 2-25-2019)
5-4C-7: IMPOUNDMENT; REDEMPTION:
A. Impounding: It shall be the duty of the animal control officer or the officers of the Police Department to take up and impound, in such
place as shall be provided by the City Council for that purpose to be known as the "animal pound", any dog or cat running at large
within the City in violation of section 5-4C-1 of this article.
B. Capture, Transporting:
1. Method Of Capture: The animal control officer and his/her assistants shall be allowed the use of leashes, nets and tranquilizer
guns as means of taking up and impounding animals specified in this chapter. The use of a tranquilizer gun shall be allowed only
after an authorized individual has been properly instructed in its use by a qualified instructor previously approved by a majority
vote of the City Council.
2. Transporting: The Animal Control Department shall provide means of transporting impounded animals specified in this article from
place of capture to the pound. Transportation may include the use of:
a. A portable pen temporarily or permanently mounted in a vehicle which is property of the animal control officer or his/her
assistants; or
b. A portable pen temporarily or permanently mounted in a City-owned vehicle assigned temporarily or permanently for animal
control purposes; or
c. A specially designed City-owned vehicle assigned for animal control purposes.
C. Notice Of Impoundment:
1. Determination Of Ownership: When any dog or cat displaying an inoculation tag, license tag, or tattoo registered with the City shall
be impounded, the animal control officer shall make a search of the City records or contact the veterinarian who issued the
inoculation tag to determine the owner thereof and shall immediately provide the apparent owner thereof, if any, with written notice.
The notice shall be delivered by certified, return receipt requested mail.
2. Notice: The notice provided for in subsection C1 of this section shall be in the following or a similar form:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=989 101/251
NOTICE
You are hereby notified that a ( ) male ( ) female dog/cat ( ) believed to be owned by you ( ) of which you are the registered
licensed owner, has been impounded by the Animal Control Officer of the City of Colona because the dog/cat was found to be
running at large ( ) with ( ) without a proper license.
As the owner of the dog/cat, you are liable for a fine up to seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for violation of Title 5, Chapter 4,
Article C of the City Code.
You may redeem the dog/cat upon showing the Animal Control Officer that the dog/cat has been inoculated and upon payment
of a redemption fee of $20.00 for the first offense and $40.00 for each offense thereafter and the current tax if the same is unpaid.
Such fees shall be paid to the Animal Control Officer.
If redemption of the dog/cat is not made within seven (7) days from the time of impoundment or by A.M./P.M. on , the dog/cat
shall be disposed of in accordance with the provisions of subsection 5-4C-7H of the City Code.
You are hereby notified that if you do not appear within five (5) days of the date of this notice, I will appear before the Circuit
Court of Henry County and sign a complaint formally charging you with violation of Title 5, Chapter 4, Article C of the City Code.
Animal Control Officer
D. Care Of Impounded Animals:
1. Shelter: Sufficient shelter shall be furnished in which to cause retention and in which to sustain or improve the health of
impounded animals.
2. Food: Sufficient feeding shall be furnished to sustain or improve the health of impounded animals.
3. First Aid; Medical Care: Necessary first aid and medical care shall be furnished to sustain or improve the health of impounded
animals.
E. Redemption: Any dog or cat taken up and confined in the City-authorized animal pound may be redeemed by the owner or keeper
thereof any time within seven (7) days from the time the same was impounded, upon payment of the following fees:
1. A redemption fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) for the first offense and forty dollars ($40.00) for each offense thereafter;
2. The amount of the current veterinarian inoculation fee unless current inoculation is proven;
3. The license fee imposed by section 5-4C-4 of this article unless valid license is proven;
4. Both the redemption fee and impoundment fee shall be waived for animals which were licensed at the time of impoundment and
which have not previously been impounded.
F. Removal Without Paying Fees: Any owner or keeper who shall take said dog or cat from such animal pound without payment of the
fees prescribed herein shall be subject to the penalties provided for in section 1-4-1 of this Code.
G. Exempt Animals: It shall be the discretion of the animal control officer to exempt animals violating the provisions of this article after
being shown by the owner or keeper proof of restraint or failure.
H. Disposition Of Unclaimed Animals: All dogs or cats not redeemed within seven (7) days from the time the same was impounded shall,
under the direction of the Chief of Police or animal control officer be destroyed by a qualified employee or veterinarian.
I. Liability Of Owners Or Keepers: Owners or keepers identified of unclaimed animals will be held liable for all expenses incurred
including pickup fees, boarding fees, euthanasia and disposal of such animal. Owner or keeper will also be held liable for any other
expenses such as attorney fees that may arise due to the animal remaining unclaimed. (1997 Code)
5-4C-8: INJURED ANIMALS:
A. Picked Up By Animal Control Officer: The animal control officer shall remove from any street or public place within the City any
injured dog or cat not being attended and properly cared for by the owner and shall, if the animal control officer deems it advisable,
impound and confine the dog or cat with some veterinarian within the City.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=989 102/251
B. Veterinary Costs: If the veterinarian shall treat the injured dog or cat, the veterinarian shall advise the animal control officer of the cost
of the treatment and in the event such dog or cat is redeemed as provided in this article, the person redeeming the dog or cat shall
pay the charges of the veterinarian.
C. Unredeemed Animal: If the dog or cat is not redeemed, it shall be disposed of in the manner provided in this article. (1997 Code)
5-4C-9: ANIMALS IN ESTRUS:
No owner or keeper of any female dog or cat shall permit the dog or cat to run at large within the City while in "heat". Any female dog or
cat found running at large should be taken up and impounded in the animal pound and the dog or cat shall be disposed of, or may be
redeemed upon the payment of the same fees and in the same manner as dogs and cats may be redeemed which have been
impounded. Anyone found guilty of violating this section shall be subject to penalty as provided in section 1-4-1 of this Code. (1997
Code; amd. Ord. 0-19-01, 2-25-2019)
5-4C-10: DISTURBING THE PEACE:
No person shall permit, allow, keep, or harbor in such a way as to permit or allow any dog or cat to unduly disturb the quiet of a
neighborhood within the City. Any dog or cat that unduly disturbs the quiet of a neighborhood is declared to be a nuisance. (1997 Code)
5-4C-11: ANIMAL BITES:
A. Notification Of Bite; Leaving City Prohibited: No owner or keeper of any dog or cat, when notified that such dog or cat has bitten any
person or has so injured any person as to cause an abrasion of the skin, shall sell or give away such dog or cat or permit or allow the
dog or cat to be taken beyond the limits of the City. (1997 Code)
B. Confinement; Cost: It shall be the duty of the owner or keeper, upon receiving notice of such an injury caused by the dog or cat, from
the animal control officer, or otherwise, to surrender possession of the dog or cat to the animal control officer for confinement at a
licensed veterinary clinic in the City for not less than ten (10) days, the cost of such confinement to be paid by the owner or keeper.
Anyone found guilty of violating this section shall be subject to penalty as provided in section 1-4-1 of this Code. (1997 Code; amd.
Ord. 0-19-01, 2-25-2019)
5-4C-12: VICIOUS ANIMALS:
5-4C-12-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this section 5-4C-12, the following terms and phrases shall have the meanings set forth in this section:
BITE: To seize or cut with the teeth.
CONFINEMENT STRUCTURE: A securely locked pen, kennel or structure designed and constructed for the keeping of a vicious dog
shall be designed, constructed and maintained in accordance with the standards herein. Such pen, kennel or structure must have
secure sides and a secure top attached to the sides. All structures used to confine a City registered and licensed vicious dog must be
locked with a key or combination lock when such animals are within the structure. Such structure must have a secure bottom or floor
attached to the sides of the pen or the sides must be embedded in the ground no less than two feet (2'). All structures erected to house
vicious dogs must comply with all zoning and building regulations of the City. All such structures erected to house vicious dogs must be
adequately lighted, ventilated and kept in a clean and sanitary condition.
FIGHT: A prearranged conflict between two (2) or more animals but does not include a conflict that is unorganized or accidental.
K-9 PATROL OR POLICE DOG: A professionally trained dog used by law enforcement officers for law enforcement and activities.
LEASH: A cord, chain, rope, strap, or other such physical restraint having a tensile strength of not less than three hundred (300)
pounds.
MUZZLE: A device constructed of strong, soft material or a metal muzzle. The muzzle must be made in a manner which will not cause
injury to the dog or interfere with its vision or respiration, but must prevent it from biting any person or animal.
NIP: To pinch or squeeze with teeth with no breaking of skin or tissue.
RUNNING AT LARGE: The failure to confine a vicious dog in accordance with section 5-4C-1 of this article.
VICIOUS DOG: Any dog that has, without provocation attacked a human being or other animal, or a dog that by its behavior or physical
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=989 103/251
condition constitutes an immediate and serious physical or health threat to human beings or animals, or any dog which has previously
attacked or bitten any human being or other animal on two (2) or more reported occasions, or a dog that has been determined to be a
vicious or dangerous dog as set forth in section 5-4C-12-2 of this article. (Ord. 0-11-14, 7-14-2014)
5-4C-12-2: DETERMINED DANGEROUS:
A. Notice Of Determination: When in the judgment of the animal control officer a dog may pose a danger or threat to the safety of the
residents of the city by reason of the dog's actions or past conduct, the animal control officer may issue to the owner or keeper of
such dog a written notice stating that the animal control officer has deemed such dog to be a threat or danger to the residents of the
city and set forth the reasons for that judgment.
B. Failure To Comply: Failure of the owner or keeper of such dog to comply with the requirements of this section 5-4C-12 in the time set
by the animal control officer shall constitute a violation of this section 5-4C-12 and each day the owner or keeper of such dog fails to
comply with the requirements of this section 5-4C-12 shall constitute a new violation. (Ord. 0-11-14, 7-14-2014)
5-4C-12-3: LICENSING:
A. License Required: No person shall possess any vicious dog for a period of more than forty eight (48) hours without having first
obtained a license therefor from the city.
B. Application; Fee: An application for a license to possess a vicious dog shall be filed with the Colona police department on a form
prescribed and provided by the Colona police department and shall be accompanied by all of the following:
1. Verification Of Identity Of Owner: Verification of the identity of the owner and current address by providing a photostatic copy of
the owner's driver's license.
2. Proof Of Ownership: Proof of ownership of the vicious dog.
3. Current Immunization And Health Records: A copy of the current immunization and health record of the vicious dog by a
veterinarian licensed to practice in the state.
4. Certificate Of Insurance: A certificate of insurance evidencing coverage in an amount not less than three hundred thousand dollars
($300,000.00) providing coverage for any injury, damage or loss caused by the vicious dog.
5. Photographs: Two (2) photographs of the vicious dog to be licensed taken not less than one month before the application. One
photograph shall provide a front view of the vicious dog and shall clearly show the face and ears of the vicious dog. One
photograph shall show a side view of the vicious dog.
6. License Fee: A license fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00).
7. Additional Information: Such other information as may be required by the animal control officer.
8. Annual Submittal: All fees, inspections and licensing requirements of this subsection B are due annually.
C. Inspection Of Premises: Upon receipt of an application, the police department shall forward such application to the animal control
officer who shall cause an inspection of the premises on which the vicious dog shall be kept to determine that all provisions of this
section 5-4C-12 relating to the confinement and posting of signs have been complied with by the applicant. Upon completion of the
inspection, the animal control officer shall notify the Colona police department in writing of the results of his/her inspection.
D. Approval/Denial Of Application: Upon receipt of the results of the animal control officer's inspection the animal control officer shall
notify the applicant of the approval or denial of the license. In the event the animal control officer is not available the chief of police
will designate another employee of the Colona police department who shall notify the applicant of the approval or denial of the
license. In the event that the license is denied, the notification shall be provided in writing and the reasons for such denial shall be
stated. Upon approval, the Colona police department shall issue a license to the applicant. (Ord. 0-11-14, 7-14-2014)
5-4C-12-4: CONFINEMENT:
No person shall possess any vicious dog unless the vicious dog is confined in accordance with this section.
A. Indoors: No vicious dog may be kept on a porch, patio or in any part of a house or structure that would allow the vicious dog to exit
the structure when the windows are open or when screen windows or screen doors are the only obstacle preventing the vicious dog
from exiting the structure.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=989 104/251
B. Exterior Yard: No person shall confine a vicious dog in an exterior area unless such vicious dog is confined in a confinement structure
constructed and maintained in accordance with this section 5-4C-12, except that a vicious dog may be confined outside of a
confinement structure in a manner set forth in subsection C of this section.
C. Leash: No person shall permit a vicious dog to go outside a confinement structure, house or other structure unless the vicious dog is
securely restrained with a leash no longer than three feet (3') in length and fitted with a muzzle. No person shall permit a vicious dog
to be kept on a leash unless a person is in physical control of the leash. No leash restraining any vicious dog shall be attached to
any inanimate object including, but not limited to, trees, posts, stakes, and buildings. (Ord. 0-11-14, 7-14-2014)
5-4C-12-5: REPORTING REQUIREMENTS OF LICENSEE:
Any person holding a license pursuant to this section 5-4C-12 shall report the incidence of any of the following events:
A. Change In Ownership; Death: The sale, barter, exchange, gift or death of any vicious dog shall be reported within forty eight (48)
hours.
B. Escape; Theft: The escape from confinement or theft of any vicious dog shall be reported upon discovery of the escape or theft.
C. Biting Or Nipping: Biting or nipping of any person or animal by a vicious dog shall be reported upon occurrence.
D. Birth Of Offspring: The birth of any offspring of a vicious dog shall be reported within forty eight (48) hours of the birth of the offspring.
E. Permanent Removal: The permanent removal of any vicious dog from the territorial limits of the city shall be reported within forty eight
(48) hours of such removal by surrender of the license of the owner to the city clerk.
Except as provided in this section, the report of any incident required to be reported under this section shall be made to the animal
control officer. (Ord. 0-11-14, 7-14-2014)
5-4C-12-6: SIGN REQUIRED:
All persons possessing a vicious dog shall display in a prominent place on the premises where the vicious dog is to be kept a sign which
is readable by the public from a distance of not less than one hundred feet (100') using the words "Beware Of Vicious Dog". A similar
sign shall be posted on a confinement structure. (Ord. 0-11-14, 7-14-2014)
5-4C-12-7: FIGHTING PROHIBITED:
No person shall fight or bait, conspire to fight or bait, or keep, train, or transport for the purpose of fighting or baiting, any pit bull dog
and/or vicious dog. (Ord. 0-11-14, 7-14-2014)
5-4C-12-8: IMPOUNDMENT:
A. Vicious Dog: Any dog which by its actions is a "vicious dog" as defined herein shall be subject to immediate impoundment by the
animal control officer in a humane facility for the keeping of dogs. If the incident giving rise to the impoundment has resulted in an
injury to a person, upon impoundment by the animal control officer, the chief of police or his/her designee shall notify the rabies
control administrator of the county pursuant to 510 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/12, and shall transfer control of the vicious dog to the
administrator in accordance with 510 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/13.
B. Running At Large: Any known vicious dog found to be running at large by the animal control officer or any member of the police
department shall be presumed to be in violation of this section 5-4C-12 and shall be subject to impoundment by the animal control
officer in a humane facility for the keeping of dogs.
C. Redemption: An owner of a vicious dog holding a license pursuant to this section 5-4C-12 may redeem an impounded vicious dog if:
1) a vicious dog has been impounded pursuant to this section, or 2) a vicious dog has not caused injury to a person subject to the
following conditions:
1. Proof of a valid license issued by the City under this section 5-4C-12.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=989 105/251
2. Payment of the cost of keeping the vicious dog during the period of impoundment.
An owner of a vicious dog which has caused an injury to a person resulting in the impoundment of the vicious dog shall be entitled
to redeem the vicious dog in accordance with 510 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/12. (Ord. 0-11-14, 7-14-2014)
5-4C-12-9: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
A license granted pursuant to this section 5-4C-12 shall be automatically revoked upon any violation by the licensee of any provision of
this section 5-4C-12. In the event of a revocation of the license, the license fee shall be retained by the City. Upon revocation of license,
owner of said animal shall have twenty four (24) hours to remove the animal from the City. (1997 Code)
5-4C-12-10: EXCEPTIONS:
This section 5-4C-12 shall not apply to any "K-9 patrol dogs" or "police dogs" as defined herein. (1997 Code)
5-4C-12-11: PENALTY:
A. Violation: Upon conviction of a violation of any section or subsection of this section 5-4C-12, the court shall assess a fine as provided
in section 1-4-1 of this Code.
B. Court Order: Upon a finding by the court that a licensee has violated section 5-4C-12-4, 5-4C-12-5 or 5-4C-12-7 of this section 5-4C-
12, the City shall enter an order revoking the license and ordering the former holder of the license to remove the pit bull dog and/or
vicious dog from the City. (1997 Code)
5-4C-13: PROCEDURE FOR SUSPECTED RABIES:
Any dog or cat having symptoms of the disease known as rabies shall be confined under the supervision of a veterinarian for a period of
ten (10) days. Any dog or cat having any symptoms of rabies when impounded by the animal control officer shall be immediately placed
in the care of a veterinarian. If it shall be deemed that the dog or cat is suffering from rabies, the animal may not be destroyed without
specific authorization of the veterinarian. Anyone found guilty of violating this section shall be subject to penalty as provided in section 1-
4-1 of this Code. (1997 Code; amd. Ord. 0-19-01, 2-25-2019)
5-4C-14: DESTROYING ANIMALS:
Whoever wilfully and maliciously abandons, kills, wounds, maims, disfigures or poisons any dog or cat or exposes poisonous
substances with the intent that the life of any dog or cat should be destroyed thereby, such dog or cat being the property of another or
said owner or keeper himself/herself, shall be subject to the penalties provided for in this Code. Anyone found guilty of violating this
section shall be subject to penalty as provided in section 1-4-1 of this Code. (1997 Code; amd. Ord. 0-19-01, 2-25-2019)
5-4C-15: MONTHLY REPORT:
The animal control officer shall, on a monthly basis, make a report to the City Council of all fees, fines, and warrants; and shall keep a
log of all calls and further report said calls on said log. (1997 Code)
5-4C-16: KENNELING DOGS IN FRONT YARDS:
A. It shall be unlawful to kennel, house, chain, tie up, or otherwise keep a dog or dogs in any part of the front yard of a property being
used as a residence.
B. "Front yard" shall be defined as an open space extending the full width of a lot between a building and the front lot line, unoccupied
and unobstructed from the ground upward.
C. The property owner, all occupants of the residence, and the owners of the dog or dogs shall each be jointly and/or severally liable for
compliance with this section.
D. Any property not in compliance with this section shall be brought into compliance within sixty (60) days after the effective date hereof.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=989 106/251
E. Should any portion of this section be deemed illegal, then only that portion of the section that is illegal shall be stricken and all other
portions shall remain in full force and effect.
F. Each day the violation exists is a separate offense.
G. The fine for violating this section is not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00).
H. Violation of this section shall also be part of the "no contest" procedure and ordinance previously enacted. The "no contest" fine shall
be seventy five dollars ($75.00). (Ord. 98-10, 11-9-1998)
I. Any property owner, occupant of the residence or the dog owner may petition the Colona Police Commission for a variance from this
section if the layout or construction of the residence makes compliance with this section impossible or impractical. The Colona Police
Commission shall conduct a hearing on the petition at which time the petitioner may informally present evidence. If the commission
finds the compliance is impossible or impractical then a variance may be granted under such terms and conditions as it sees fit. The
commission shall issue a written decision and mail a copy to the petitioner when issued. Any notice of appeal to the Police
Commission's decision must be filed with the City Clerk within ten (10) days of issuance of the written decision of the Police
Commission. The appeal will be scheduled for review by the full City Council within forty (40) days of the filing of the notice of appeal.
The City Council will review the findings of the Police Commission and issue written findings and decision. The decision will be final
and appealable upon signing by the Mayor. (Ord. 98-10, 11-9-1998; amd. Ord. 0-15-001, 3-24-2015)
Chapter 5
FINES
5-5-1: NO CONTEST FINE:
In the event that a person is accused of a violation and does not wish to contest said allegation, then said person so accused may pay
to the City at police headquarters or pay online within fourteen (14) days from the date of the citation (the date of issuance included) for
and in full satisfaction of said violation a fine in the amount of the minimum penalty, which minimum penalty shall be one hundred dollars
($100.00) unless otherwise listed in this Code1. In the event the accused person avails himself or herself of the foregoing provisions of
this section, then no court appearance, court costs, administrative hearing appearance or administrative hearing costs shall be required.
(Ord. 0-18-04, 1-22-2018)
5-5-2: GEOMETRIC PROGRESSION OF FINE:
Ordinance violation fees and/or fines assessed under no contest offenses shall be doubled for repeat offenders during the period of
twelve (12) months following the date of their last ticket for the same offense. Every violation fee continues to double until a twelve (12)
month period of being violation free of the same offense.
Example: A March 2010 ticket followed by a September 2010 ticket for the same offense: If March fine was twenty five dollars ($25.00)
the September fine would be fifty dollars ($50.00) and if a third ticket is incurred within twelve (12) months the September ticket and fine
would be one hundred dollars ($100.00) and the doubling of the last fine shall continue until the arrested person is free of such offense
for a twelve (12) month period following their last ticket for the offense. (Ord. 0-15-10, 5-10-2010)
Title 6
MOTOR VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC
Chapter 1
GENERAL TRAFFIC PROVISIONS1
6-1-1: DEFINITIONS:
Whenever in this title the following terms are used, they shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section:
ALLEY: A public way within a block, generally giving access to the rear of lots or buildings, and not used for general traffic circulation.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=989 107/251
BICYCLE: Every device propelled by human power upon which any person may ride, having two (2) tandem wheels except scooters
and similar devices.
CROSSWALK: A. That part of a roadway at an intersection included within the connections of the lateral lines of the sidewalks on
opposite sides of the highway measured from the curbs or, in the absence of curbs, from the edges of the traversable roadway, and in
the absence of a sidewalk on one side of the highway, that part of the highway included within the extension of the lateral line of the
existing sidewalk to the side of the highway without the sidewalk, with such extension forming a right angle to the centerline of the
highway;
B. Any portion of a roadway at an intersection or elsewhere distinctly indicated for pedestrian crossing by lines or other markings on
the surface placed in accordance with the provisions in the manual adopted by the department of transportation.
DRIVER: Every person who drives or is in actual physical control of a vehicle.
EMERGENCY VEHICLE: Police vehicles, vehicles of fire department, ambulances, vehicles carrying a state, county or municipal officer
or employee in response to an emergency call, and emergency vehicles of public service corporations on emergency call.
INTERSECTION: A. The area embraced within the prolongation or connection of the lateral curb lines, or, if none, then the lateral
boundary lines of the roadways of two (2) highways which join one another at, or approximately at, right angles or the area within which
vehicles traveling upon different roadways joining at any other angle may come in conflict.
B. Where a highway includes two (2) roadways forty feet (40') or more apart, then every crossing of each roadway of such divided
highway by an intersecting highway shall be regarded as a separate intersection.
C. The junction of an alley with a street or highway does not constitute an intersection.
METAL TIRES: Every tire the surface of which in contact with the roadway is wholly or partially of metal or other hard, nonresilient
material.
MOTOR VEHICLE: Every vehicle which is self-propelled.
MOTORCYCLE: Every motor vehicle having a saddle for the use of the rider and designed to travel on not more than three (3) wheels in
contact with the ground, but excluding a tractor.
PARK: To stand a vehicle whether occupied or not, for a period of time greater than is reasonably necessary for the actual loading or
unloading of persons.
PEDESTRIAN: Any person afoot.
PNEUMATIC TIRES: Every tire in which compressed air is designed to support the load.
PROPERTY LINE: The line making the boundary between any street and the lots or property abutting thereto.
